Arne Janssen

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/4948469886248019
  • Última atualização do currículo em 19/06/2019

Possui mestrado em Ecology - Leiden University (1983) e doutorado em Ecology - University of Amsterdam (1994). Atualmente é professor associado - University of Amsterdam, pesquisador da Universidade Federal de Viçosa. Tem experiência na área de Ecologia, com ênfase em biologia populacional, atuando principalmente nos seguintes temas: controle biológico, acari predadores, teias alimentares, interação predador-presa, comportamento, defesa de planta. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2003 - Atual
The effect of intraguild predation on stability and persiste
Descrição: Current theory predicts that intraguild predation, the killing and eating of species that use similar resources and are thus potential competitors, often leads to exclusion of species and destabilization of food webs. This is in contradiction with the observation that intraguild predation occurs frequently in natural ecosystems. However, critical tests of the theory are lacking, mainly because the resource is difficult to characterize in the experimental systems used until now. A critical test will either confirm the existing theory or reject it, the last result indicating that the current models are too simplistic, and further experimental and theoretical studies should the reveal mechanisms for coexistence with intraguild predation. The most essential parameter for the model predictions is the productivity of the habitat: coexistence of a system of 3 species with intraguild predation is only possible for intermediate productivity. Hence, experiments testing the theory should measure the effects of manipulating productivity on coexistence and persistence of the species. We propose to perform such experiments using two simple acarine systems. These systems have the advantage over experimental systems used so far that the resource level (i.e. productivity) is easy to manipulate experimentally, that the generation time of the mites are short, and the species are easy to maintain on small experimental arenas. One system will be used to test the current theory, while the other will serve to investigate the often-occurring reciprocal intraguild predation (i.e. when 2 competitors eat each other's juvenile stages), parallel to further development of models to include the effects of such, commonly occurring reciprocal intraguild predation..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Arne Janssen - Coordenador / Maurice W Sabelis - Integrante / Marta Montserrat - Integrante / Andre M de Roos - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Netherlands Organization For Scientific Research Nwo - Bolsa.
2002 - Atual
Adaptation of Pests and their Natural Enemies to Eucalyptus
Descrição: Although there is much evidence for the occurrence of adaptation to novel, introduced hosts plant species in insect herbivores, there is much less evidence for a trade-off in ability to use new hosts and native hosts as a food source. This is important for host race formation and ecological speciation, because absence of such trade-off would enable insects to easily move back to the native host, causing substantial gene flow between populations on novel and native hosts, leading to diet extension and a more generalist herbivore species. Besides looking for such trade-offs, we suggest to study another mechanism that would reduce gene flow from herbivore populations on novel hosts to native hosts, which is the absence of specialist natural enemies on novel host plants. Absence of predators and parasitoids on novel host plants will lead to relaxation of the selection pressure on traits associated with the avoidance or reduction of predation, resulting in a decrease of defensive capacity of the herbivores. Upon returning to the native host, herbivorous insects may face increased predation risks relative to the original population, and this could well reduce gene flow between populations on novel and native hosts. We aim to study these mechanisms in Eucalyptus forests in Brazil. Since its introduction, this tree is attacked by a variety of herbivores from native Brazilian plants, whereas their enemies have remained ineffective in controlling them on Eucalyptus. Studying the adaptation of herbivores and their natural enemies to this novel host will yield insights into the effect of natural enemies on gene flow between populations on novel and native hosts and contribute to the development of sustainable crop protection..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Arne Janssen - Coordenador / Maurice W Sabelis - Integrante / Madelaine Venzon - Integrante / Amir Grosman - Integrante / Angelo Pallini - Integrante / Steph Menken - Integrante / Hans Breeuwer - Integrante / O de Souza - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Netherlands Organization For Tropical Research - Bolsa.
2001 - Atual
Africa-Wide Biological Control of Green Mites on Cassava:
Descrição: Plants interact with herbivores in a variety of ways, one of them is the provision of shelter to natural enemies of herbivores. Many plant species possess specific structures, called domatia, which are often inhabited by beneficial arthropods, such as predatory mites. It is hypothesised that, through these structures, plants and beneficials have a mutualistic relationship: The plants offer shelter from adverse abiotic conditions (UV-light, wind rain) while the beneficial mites protect the plants against pests and diseases. Despite some recent attempts, the ?mutualism? hypothesis still lacks critical testing. We propose such a test, using the tropical crop Cassava as a plant species. Cassava has apices with specific domatia-like structures that are inhabited by predatory mites, an important natural enemies of a ravenous, herbivorous mite, the cassava green mite (Bakker, Thesis University of Amsterdam). We will attempt to measure effects of these apical domatia on predatory mites and effects of predatory mites, through domatia, on cassava green mites and on plant damage (i.e. crop yield). In particular, we intend to investigate differences in the structure of the apex between cassava-varieties and to assess how these different structures affect the control of cassava green mites. Besides yielding insight in the coevolution between plants and beneficial arthropods, the results of this study may well improve crop protection on cassava in Africa..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Arne Janssen - Integrante / Maurice W Sabelis - Coordenador / Rachid Hanna - Integrante / Alexis Onzo - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Netherlands Organization For Tropical Research - Bolsa.
2000 - Atual
Plant-predator mutualisms: coffee plants provide shelter to
Descrição: Plants interact with herbivores in a variety of ways, one of them is the provision of shelter to natural enemies of herbivores. Many plant species possess specific structures, called domatia, which are often inhabited by beneficial (fungivorous or predatory) mites. It is hypothesised that, through these structures, plants and beneficials have a mutualistic relationship: The plants offer shelter from adverse abiotic conditions while the beneficial mites protect the plants against pests and diseases. Indeed elimination of the beneficial mites leads to an increase in damage by herbivores. Despite some recent attempts, the ?mutualism? hypothesis still lacks critical testing. We propose such a test, using the tropical cash crop coffee as a plant species. Coffee has distinct domatia that are inhabited by beneficial mites. We will attempt to measure effects of domatia on mites and effects of mites, through domatia, on plant fitness (i.e. crop yield). Besides yielding insight in the coevolution between plants and beneficials, results of this study can also be used to improve crop protection in coffee, with reduced use of pesticides..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Arne Janssen - Coordenador / Maurice W Sabelis - Integrante / Joao Ferreira - Integrante / Angelo Pallini - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Netherlands Organization For Tropical Research - Bolsa.
2000 - Atual
Indirect interactions and their effect on biological control
Descrição: The increased use of biological control for crop protection leads to the formation of artificial food webs. As a consequence, interactions between plants, pests and natural enemies change from simple tritrophic interactions to more complex food web interactions. As a result, densities of pests are not only determined by interactions with their natural enemies, but also by direct and indirect interactions with other pests and enemies. However, studies on the effects of such indirect interactions on the dynamics of pests and natural enemies are still lacking. This proposal aims at bridging this gap by combining population experiments and model studies, concentrating on two simple systems consisting of two pests, the two-spotted spider mite Tetranychus urticae and the western flower thrips Frankliniella occidentalis, and their natural enemies, the predatory mites Phytoseiulus persimilis, Iphiseius degenerans, Neoseiulus cucumeris or the predatory bug Orius laevigatus..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (0) .

Integrantes: Arne Janssen - Coordenador / Maurice W Sabelis - Integrante / Sara Magalhaes - Integrante / Belen Belliure - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Praxis - Bolsa / European Community - Bolsa.
Número de produções C, T & A: 2
2000 - Atual
Plant-predator mutualisms: coffee plants provide shelter to

2000 - Atual
The response of truffle beetles to odurs of truffles
Descrição: Truffles are famous for producing strong odours that are even distinguishable by the human nose. Several species of European truffle in the genus Tuber are highly sought after for their culinary properties, and are known to be attractive to mammals such as dogs, pigs, wild boar and humans. It is thought that the chemical compounds responsible for such attraction have evolved as a means to attract mammals that disperse the spores of these underground-dwelling fungi, suggesting that production of the odour is essential for the truffle. In contrast to the recognition of ripe truffle odours by certain mammal species, it is unknown how specialized arthropods living in or around truffle fruiting bodies may use sensory cues to recognize truffles, or whether these insects potentially act as dispersal agents for truffle spores. One of the specialized fungivores attacking truffles, the beetle, Leiodes cinnamomea Panzer (Coleoptera: Staphylinoidea) is univoltine with a European distribution. It is known to feed on several species of truffle (Tuber sp.), completing its life cycle in or near the fungal fruiting body (e.g., Arzone 1970; Newton 1984). The Black Truffle is one of the most highly valued truffles in the Tuber genus, but truffles that are attacked by beetles are substantially lower in marketing value than unattacked truffles. It is therefore essential to study the ecology of this species. We hypothesize that truffle beetle use odours of truffles to localize them..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (0) .

Integrantes: Arne Janssen - Integrante / Michael E Hochberg - Coordenador / Guillaume Bertault - Integrante / Karine Poitrineau - Integrante / Patrick Réjou - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique - Cooperação.
2000 - Atual
Analysis of spatial ecological data
Descrição: The aim of the project is to develop a new statistical method for analysis of spatio-temporal ecological data and to apply them to experimental data of a long-term experiment on persistence of predators and prey in a metapopulation structure. This method could be used to estimate growth rates and dispersal and estimate the characteristic spatial scale of the predator-prey interaction..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (0) .

Integrantes: Arne Janssen - Integrante / Vincent Jansen - Coordenador / Anne Schneeberger - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Uk Embassy - Bolsa.
1999 - 2003
Interactions and the local environment
Descrição: The impact of space on the dynamics of interacting species has received increasing interest from both ecologists and theoreticians over the last decade. Initially, attention focussed on the stabilizing influence of dispersing individuals among spatially disjoined habitat patches with local populations of competitors or predator and prey. Subsequently, spatial pattern formation or self-organization became a focus of a large number of studies. Still more recently, spatially-explicit individual-based models have received a lot of attention. Most of these models are based on the assumption of random search of predators and ,if not, on phenomenological assumption on the distributions that may arise from non-random search. In this proposal emphasis will be on the dynamical consequences of flexible searching behaviour..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (0) .

Integrantes: Arne Janssen - Integrante / Maurice W Sabelis - Integrante / Marta Montserrat - Integrante / Andre M de Roos - Coordenador.
Financiador(es): Netherlands Organization For Scientific Research Nwo - Bolsa.
Número de produções C, T & A: 4
1998 - 2000
Sex, thelythoky and adaptation in the false spider mite
Descrição: Thelytoky (female parthenogenesis) is often thought to be an evolutionary dead end compared to sexual reproduction, because it increases homozygosity and mutational load and limits or inhibits genetic recombination. Because of this, thelytokous species are believed to lack genetic flexibility or ability to respond to environmental changes, and to suffer from the expression of recessive deleterious mutations. Nevertheless, there are many thelytokous species among mites and insects, which suggest that under certain conditions thelytoky can be successful. An example is the thelytokous false spider mite Brevipalpus phoenicis. This species is unique among the thelytokes. It is the only known example with haploid thelytoky, and is essentially apomictic. But yet, it is extremely polyphagous and widely distributed in the tropics and sub-tropics. In addition, it is a major pest on citrus in Brazil and tea in Indonesia, because it develops resistance to acaricides rapidly and vectors citrus leprosis virus. The extreme adaptability and thelytokous mode of reproduction present a paradox: adaptation requires genetic variation, but thelytoky restricts the generation of genetic variation. Solving this paradox requires genetic studies of the degree and origin of clonal variation and its consequences for the evolution (adaptability) of thelytoky. The Postdoc project aims at investigating this..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (0) .

Integrantes: Arne Janssen - Integrante / Hans Breeuwer - Coordenador / Andrew Weeks - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Netherlands Organization For Tropical Research - Bolsa.
1997 - 2003
Biological control of the whitefly Bemisia tasbaci with pred
Descrição: The tobacco whitefly Bemisia tabaci poses a real threat for growers of greenhouse crops in Europe. It is a relatively new pest, accidentally introduced from the USA. The whitefly causes direct damage to plants by its feeding activity, and indirect damage due to the production of honeydew and transmission of plant pathogenic viruses. Biological control of this pest is therefore needed, the more so because chemical control is declared undesirable by the Dutch government in its Multi-Year Crop Protection Plan. Several natural enemies of B. tabaci are nowadays used in practice. The parasitoid Encarsia formosa, successful in controlling another whitefly species in greenhouses, is less successful in controlling the tobacco whitefly. Other natural enemies currently used are insect predators, but these species are either expensive, or generalistic, or both. Generalist predators are less suitable natural enemies because they can also attack the natural enemies used against other pests, thereby hampering their control. We propose to search for natural enemies in the group of predatory mites (Phytoseiidae). Predators from this group have a history of success in biological control programs. Several species are successfully used against various pests, such as spider mites and thrips. Advantages of predatory mites are that they have high population growth rates, they are cheap and easy to rear, and that they are more specialistic natural enemies than the insect predators mentioned above. Another advantage is that many predatory mite species can use plant-produced pollen as a food source, and can thus even persist in crops when no pest is present. Some 11 species of phytoseiids are known to be associated with whitefly, and 3 of those are currently available at the University of Amsterdam, whereas the remaining species will be obtained in the near future. The current proposal aims at evaluating these species as biological control agents in greenhouses..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Arne Janssen - Coordenador / Maria Nomikou - Integrante / Maurice W Sabelis - Integrante / Ruud Schraag - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Foundation For Technical Sciences - Bolsa.

Descrição: The investigation of tempo-spatial dynamics in metapopulations of acarine predator-prey systems, with emphasis on connectedness of local populations and dispersal.

1996 - 1999
Host plant selection, host race formation and speciation in
Descrição: A model on host plant selection behaviour predicts when animals should specialize on a limited host range, and when they should generalize. This depends on the probability to find high quality hosts, and the reproductive potential offered by the various host species. One prediction of the model is that an increased probability to find superior hosts will lead to specialization. Specialization, together with mating on the host will increase the probability of sympatric host race formation. Polyphagotarsonemus latus is thought to be a generalist phytophagous tropical mite pest. However, it is unclear whether all specimens identified belong to one polyphagous species, or whether it consists of host races or a group of sibling species, each specialized on a limited host range. P. latus has two modes of dispersal; one is passive transportation by wind; the other is phoretic on whiteflies, other plant pests. Phoresy will increase the probability of finding new hosts, and according to our model, the formation of host races. The two modes of dispersal and the supposed generalistic nature of P. latus make this species especially suited for studying host specialization, the formation of host races, and sympatric speciation. Phoresy will also extend the range of dispersal, and will thus limit the formation of geographic races. It is expected that sympatric host race formation will predominate in P. latus since it is phoretic, whereas the existence of regional polyphagy in the form of geographic races will be reduced compared to other mite species that disperse by wind only. The current project aims at testing these predictions by studying the occurrence of geographic and host races..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (0) .

Integrantes: Arne Janssen - Coordenador / Maurice W Sabelis - Integrante / Steph Menken - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Netherlands Organization For Tropical Research - Bolsa.
1994 - 2000
Volatile infochemicals and their effect on multiple predator
Descrição: Research on biological control has mainly focused on single species interactions between crop, pest and natural enemy. Current day practice in biological control however, encompasses the introduction of several species of natural enemies against various pests in the same crop. Because herbivores, plants and natural enemies may interact in complex ways, crops with herbivores and natural enemies have to be regarded as food webs instead of a collection of simple tritrophic food chains. These food web interactions can have serious effects on population dynamics of the constituting species. Prey species that share a common predator may for instance, show apparent competition and predators may not only compete for prey, but can also attack each other (a phenomenon called intraguild predation). Theoretical investigations show that consequences of these interactions for the population dynamics of all species are profound. This is of obvious importance for biological crop protection. The goal of the current project is to assess the occurrence and importance of indirect food web interactions in one particular crop, cucumber in greenhouses. In this crop, several pest species occur and natural enemies are released against them, whereas intraguild predation, (apparent) competition and other indirect interactions occur at various levels in the food web. We designed and developed experiments in which we can measure the probability that species of the artificial food web actually occur on the same plants, and how they will interact when on the same plant..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (3) / Doutorado: (3) .

Integrantes: Arne Janssen - Coordenador / Maurice W Sabelis - Integrante / Farid Faraji - Integrante / Madelaine Venzon - Integrante / Angelo Pallini - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Netherlands Organization For Scientific Research Nwo - Bolsa / Coordenação de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior - Bolsa / Ministry Of Agriculture - Bolsa / Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico - Bolsa.
Número de produções C, T & A: 20
1989 - 1993
Africa-Wide Biological Control of Green Mites on Cassava
Descrição: any phytophagous arthropods in the tropics have developed into pests in agricultural crops, not only in the countries of their origin, but also elsewhere in the world. To achieve biological control the 'classical' procedure is to select one or a few suitable predators from the usually very large complexes of enemies that are found associated with the pest arthropods under natural conditions. The identification of a suitable predator is virtually always based on a comparison of predatory capacities, thereby completely ignoring the interaction between predators, such as intraguild predation. Theory predicts that pest levels may either increase, decrease or even exhibit multiple steady states as a result of intraguild predation, and there is some experimental evidence for increases and decreases of pest levels as a result of introducing intraguild predators. This proposal concerns the analysis of the relative roles of different types of natural enemies within the natural enemy complex of the cassava green mite, Mononychellus tanajoa, originally a pest of cassava in South-America, but since c. 25 years also a pest in Africa. The campaign to establish classical biological control is based on the assumption that predatory mites (Acari: Phytoseiidae) from the Neotropics are the most promising candidates because of their fast numerical response to prey density and their ability to rely on alternative food..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Arne Janssen - Coordenador / Maurice W Sabelis - Integrante / Steve Yaninek - Integrante.
Financiador(es): General Directorate For International Collaboration - Bolsa.
Número de produções C, T & A: 4
1986 - 1989
Biological control of the Cassava Green Mite in Africa
Descrição: Many phytophagous arthropods in the tropics have developed into pests in agricultural crops, not only in the countries of their origin, but also elsewhere in the world. Theory predicts that pest levels may either increase, decrease or even exhibit multiple steady states as a result of intraguild predation, and there is some experimental evidence for increases and decreases of pest levels as a result of introducing intraguild predators. This proposal concerns the analysis of the relative roles of different types of natural enemies within the natural enemy complex of the cassava green mite, Mononychellus tanajoa, originally a pest of cassava in South-America, but since c. 25 years also a pest in Africa. Número de produções C, T & A: 3
1983 - 1986
Microhabitat use and interspecific competition of Drospohila
Descrição: Many species of parasitoids attack larvae of temperate woodland Drosophila species. Although each parasitoid species is more or less specilaized in one or a few host species and one or a few microhabitats, there is considerable overlap in but microhabitat use and host species. The project aims at investigating niche differentiation and microhabitat use of several species of parasitoids..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
